If you want to try bringing this to an even better state of Nirvana: Use only 1/2 lb of beef and add 1/2 pound of ground pork. Also replace skim milk with 1/2 a cup of ricotta cheese. I think you'll find you'll have some moister more flavorful meatballs.

text:
I've been using LTH's recipe for some time now and its my staple. I have subbed an egg for the milk without any problems. Also, I never have seasoned bread crumbs so I just up the Italian seasoning (can't tell you by how much cause I don't measure this recipe anymore). If I'm just making this for myself, I add some additional sriacha for more heat (or if I don't have the Frank's at home) I bake these on a slightly greased cookie sheet and flip halfway. These freeze great cooked or raw. Oh and I've used 80/20, 90/10, and 95/5 beef with these and they've all turned out great. Thanks for the recipe!!!

text:
Thank you , everyone, for the glowing reviews!  We at the LTH house LOVE these meatballs!  I almost always at least triple the recipe when I make it so I can freeze a few bags of meatballs.  I bake and then freeze the baked meatballs.  I'm kinda lazy (ok, a lot lazy) and never feel like taking the time to place the cooked meatballs on a cookie sheet, freeze them, then bag them. I'm lucky if I let them cool before I toss them in a freezer bag and chuck 'em in the freezer.  I freeze them in freezer bags without sauce.  It makes for crazy easy meals when no one planned ahead/feels like cooking! These do have a nice bite, so adjust the crushed red and hot pepper sauce (Red Hot at our house) to YOUR tastes.  I also rarely ever feel like dicing an onion (I'm lazy, remember?) so I usually sub dried minced.  I also tend to forget that my aversion to black pepper is generally abnormal, so, if you're not a freak like me, you may choose to add some black pepper, too!  Come as you are and enjoy Meatball Nirvana!  :)

text:
Hubs wanted meatballs as part of our "SuperBowl Smorgasbord."  I have my own way of making meatballs, but since I was using these on their own rather than with spaghetti, I kind of wanted to try something completely different, and in terms of how I make my Italian meatballs, these are different. Italian seasoning, oregano, garlic salt, hot pepper sauce and Worcerstershire sauce are all different additions for me and, other than omitting the red pepper and hot sauce in consideration of Hubs' sensitive innards, I resisted the strong urge to make these more compliant with what I was familiar with.  I popped half of one in my mouth and "Mmmm!" ran through my mind. They have a nice balance of flavors that will only get better once the flavors develop even further in my homemade tomato sauce, I thought.  I had Hubs taste the other half and the first word out of his meatball stuffed mouth was, "Yum!" (Trust me, he NEVER says "yum")  I've got more cooking to do to complete our smorgasbord (Go Pack!!!) but these meatballs are going to be one, fine contribution.  Way to go (again!) LovestoHost!

Excellent meatball recipe. This is good in homemade BBQ sauce or a good marinara and also in meatball sandwiches. Dosen't matter how you use it, it always turns out fantastic. I do like to use my own homemade italian seasoning and homemade seasoned bread crumbs (brush day old bread with garlic butter, bake until crispy, then run through the food processor until finely ground) in this recipe I also do what LTH does and double it because either my boys eat them all up or I'll make one batch and freeze the other. If you have any leftovers, it's even better the next day. GOOD STUFF.

text:
This recipe gets 5 stars for balance of ingredients and flavor... but gets 3 stars for instructions.  The ingredients balance well, and the meatballs have a great taste.  There are a few things I experimented with to improve this recipe.  First, I reduced the salt, and used garlic powder (not garlic salt).  I also did not dice the onion, I grated the onion on a small grater, and grated it over the bowl, so the onion juices blended into the meatballs, and you're not left with large bits of onion.  One of the biggest steps is to combine all the ingredients EXCEPT the beef, and allow this mixture to sit for 5 minute before including the beef.  This way, the bread crumbs absorb the moisture of the milk and the flavors blend.  Once you're ready to mix the beef in, use only your fingertips, and blend gently being careful not to over-blend.  Taking this step, you create a more moist, light and delicate meatball.  The instructions as written in this recipe will likely cause the meatball to get dry, dense, and hard.  Again, delicious balance of flavors, but the method of mixing the meatballs is not the best.

text:
Fantastic!! I have prepared dozens of recipes off of this site - some have even become staple meals at my home and I have never left a review. These meatballs are great! Only minor changes on my part. 
I used 2lbs lean ground beef and 1lb ground pork sausage. I basically tripled the other ingredients (I am not a seasoning measurer). I omitted pepper sauce and cut down on pepper flakes ONLY because of my kids - would have added if making for adults. I only double the seasoned bread crumbs (1 cup) and used oatmeal (1/2 cup) to finish what I needed, as I don't like the taste of the pre-seasoned breadcrumbs. Needed a little more milk. 
This made 40 meatballs larger than a golf ball. Filled my jellyroll pan. I baked for 10 minutes, then moved a little more than half of them to my pot of spagetti sauce to finish cooking on simmer. I finished baking the other half as directed and used them for meatball sandwiches the next day. 
For the meatball sandwiches, I LIGHTLY buttered split french bread, sprinkled with garlic powder, covered both sides with mozzarella and fresh parmesean cheeses and broiled till bubbly. put warmed meatballs on bread and drizzle with warmed marinara sauce - YUM! Next time, I will tear fresh basil UNDER the cheese before broiling.
Thanks lovestohost!

text:
This meatball recipe is fantastic! For those that have reviewed my recipe reviews, I double or triple the garlic which I did for this recipe. Everything else, I followed to a T and then added 2 eggs which my Italian family has always done which bulks up the meatball a bit while baking. 

I then quickly put together a meat sauce with 1 Tbsp of extra virgin olive oil, 1 Tbsp of garlic, 1/2 cup of onions, salt and pepper to taste (let these cook until the onion has lost its whiteness), 1 C of organic ground beef (cook until brown), then added 1 24 oz can of stewed/chopped tomatoes, 4 fresh tomatoes in which I blanched, chopped, and added to the sauce, 1/2 tsp. cinnamon, 1/4 tsp. nutmeg, 1/4 cup of red wine (the stronger the better). 

I then used the water from the blanched tomatoes to cook the Fettucine (which adds a delicious infused taste), and when the meatballs were done, I added them to the sauce.

Dinner was great and I'll definitely be using the recipe again. THANKS!

I have been looking for a meatball recipe for as long as I've been cooking---at least 25 years! I can't ground pork where I live, so I used 80/20 sirloin. These were by far the best meatballs I have EVER made. I only used 1/4 tsp red pepper flakes and they were still too hot for me---but other than that, they were perfect. I didn't change a thing, except I used Club cracker crumbs instead of bread crumbs.  These meatballs were reminiscent of Flora's, an old Italian eatery I frequented as a kid. I've been trying to reproduce that flavor. These are so moist, not dry at all (I mixed everything for about 20 seconds with my hand mixer to keep it from getting dense and tough). I cannot wait to try them on crusty Italian bread with marinara and melted mozzarella!

text:
The only thing I do differently (this comes from a 100 year old family italian meatball recipe) is to make a well within the meat mixture and add the parmesan cheese, bread crumbs, milk and mix them up into a slurry...and wait a few minutes.  Then combine this into the meat mixture, form into balls and let sit in the fridge for an hour to "set up."  Instead of baking them, the cooled meatballs are added into spaghetti sauce that is simmering on the stove.  Let the sauce and meatballs cook together (which I'm told from my Italian family that I married into) is the best way to avoid tough meatballs.  I have to agree with them. After an hour on the stove with bubbling tomato sauce, the meatballs are fabulous and add flavor!

OMG!! This recipe deserves 10 stars. I reduce the italian seasoning to 1 tsp and the oregano to 1/2 tsp. I used onion powder in replace of the onion. I used 2% milk instead of skim milk. For meat nachos you prepare the meat as usual but do not make meat into balls. Just leave the meat scrambled and put it an ovenproof glass pan or whatever you use to bake with. Let it cook for 10 to 15 minutes in a convection oven or in a regular oven it may take up to 20 minutes to be done. I love you lovestohost for this recipe.

text:
These were good, and easy to make.  I've always baked my meatballs, I just really like the texture much better than fried, and cooking them raw in the sauce grosses me out.  I followed this recipe exactly, with the minor exception of using 1/2 tsp red pepper flakes instead of 3/4.  The 1/2 just looked like plenty.  I like the texture of the meatballs made without egg - they're not as mushy as the egg ones can tend to be.  The only real problem I had was with the 'tangy' ingredients - the worcestershire and the Franks.  I didn't think they combined well with the other flavors, and it was even more noticeable when the meatballs were added to red sauce.  That's really the only change I would make.  It doesn't need an egg, they won't fall to pieces without it. All in all, a good recipe and one I will probably use again, with the minor changes above.  Thanks a lot for sharing, it's much appreciated!

I was looking for a main dish to have with macaroni and cheese that I was craving, and I thought of meatballs. However, I didn't know WHAT KIND of meatball I wanted to make - Italian, Swedish...? My husband then found this recipe and decided to make it since I was in charge of the mac 'n cheese dish. 

Oh my goodness. This did NOT disappoint. These meatballs were so delicious I didn't even need any sauce to serve them with. They were moist, perfectly cooked but not overcooked, with great flavor balance and texture... and a nice, subtle, palate-warming heat at the very end of the bite right as you swallow. Basically - these meatballs are amazing. If you're looking for a basic go-to meatball recipe, look no further... these meatballs are ANYTHING but basic.

This was a fantastic recipe. My second time making meatballs and this was a great guide. Very flavorful which is what I wanted in a meatball. It does have a kick which my daughter loved! But if you're a lightweight like me, just be aware. A couple of things that I did different. Doubled recipe and used half ground beef(80/20) and half ground sausage (oops, meant to grab ground pork). Added 4 tbsps of fresh parsley (had it, wanted to use some), eggs instead of milk (2 total), used minced onions because I didn't have any fresh but used freshly grated Parmesan because I DID have some of that. I followed the spice portion as best I could with a few minor changes to accommodate what I had available. I used the marinara sauce recipe from Italian Spaghetti Sauce with Meatballs and made meatball subs out of the combination. YUM!

text:
These were just ok, not enough moistness or flavor. Don't know anyone who adds oregano or italian seasoning to a meatball recipe. I add beef/pork/veal mix found in supermarkets, salt, pepper, grated romano cheese, minced onion, minced garlic, 1 egg, 1/2 c milk, 3 slices of bread, fresh parsley. Soak bread in milk, mix up with spoon, add egg & then other ingredients before adding meat mix. Mix all together & then fry up a little meat in a pan to taste for seasonings. You can add more seasonings to your own taste. Then bake in oven or fry in pan. Add to sauce & simmer for 1/2 hour or serve just from the oven with some grated cheese on top.  Delicious!!!! & moist.  For extra moistness, try adding 1/2 cup ricotta cheese instead of milk.

text:
I had to make some weird changes because certain ingredients were unexpectedly missing from my fridge! Instead of an actual onion, I used a Tbsp of dried minced onion, and apparently the author of this recipe has done the same thing, so I feel better about it, haha. Also, I used Sriracha for my red pepper sauce .

Here's where I had to be VERY creative. I had no milk (my husband drank the last of it the night before and didn't tell me!), and my bread crumbs were unseasoned. Since I figured the milk was meant to add moisture to the mix, and I needed some sort of seasoning to make up for the bread crumbs.... I used 1/4 cup of Italian salad dressing with the crumbs I had. Weird, I know, but it worked fairly well. The meatballs were slightly less sturdy, and there was some oil runoff (from the dressing, no doubt) but for 98% of the time they held up while I picked them up off the baking sheet, and they tasted fantastic! My husband loved them so much, he kept bugging me to bring out the leftovers (of which we had plenty, which was also awesome about the recipe) in the following days.

These are spactacular.  I prefer walnut-sized meatballs (This recipe made 30) so they can be more managable when used in sandwiches, so I only baked them for 13 minutes or so.  I also would recommend turning them during cooking, otherwise they have a flat side that's browner.  Also, when making any meatball you have to remember that mixing and rolling these is an art.  If they're over-mixed and or over rolled, they become too dense.  LOVE these MEATBALLS! THANKS!

I tripled the recipe, used just the 1 onion, used probably a half-cup of milk (because my onion was ground to bits in the food processor -- I added its juices too), and reduced the salt. It amuses me that the majority of people who didn't like them complain that there's too much flavor here. Look, anyone can make flavorless meatballs -- do you really need a recipe for that? But -- if you are looking for meatballs that do not need to be drowned in your great grandmother's secret recipe special sauce with weird ingredients or words you need a dictionary for -- here's your recipe, a meatball that'll stand on its own, do its job in a sandwich, or make your old marinara sauce seem new again. Thanks, LTH! (Tripling this recipe yielded 45 spaghetti-meatballs and 20 meatball sub meatballs, baking at 400 for 20 and 22 minutes respectively.)

For the reviewers who complained about dry tough meatballs I offer this advice.
First mix up dry ingredients then add wet, let this sit 10 min to soften the crumbs. Then mix in meat, be careful not to over mix or the meat will get tough.

text:
Rated this 4 stars due to making some changes based on other reviews. Gotta say how much I appreciate the reviews and suggestions on how to make a good recipe even better, because we really hate to waste food and money if something doesn't turn out. So...doubled the recipe to freeze extras. Used egg instead of milk, garlic powder instead of garlic salt, sauted the onion and minced garlic to soften. Left out hot sauce and red pepper flakes but added a touch of cayenne and onion powder. Little less Italian seasoning and Italian breadcrumbs. Mixed all the seasonings well before adding beef and egg and Worcestershire. Cooked 20 meatballs at 400 for 35 minutes. We love them! Try not to get upset over changes, everybody's tastes are different and reading some less positive reviews can spare wasted time and money.

text:
This is a DELICIOUS meatball recipe and it's super easy to make! My husband compliments it every time I make them. I've played around with it a little bit and the one most important thing I've learned is that you cannot leave out the Parmesan cheese - it totally changes the flavor and they aren't nearly as good. i used a teaspoon of tapateo for the hot pepper sauce and it gives them great flavor without making them spicy. I'm a wimp and can't handle spicy foods. Too much pepper and my mouth is burning. The one thing I DON'T like about this recipe is actually the baking style. They tend to get all black and crusty on the bottoms because of baking in their own grease. SIMPLE REMEDY though: place a cookie drying rack inside of your cookie sheet so that the grease can drip through. Works great!

My whole family thinks these are awesome! And they really couldn't be much easier.
I use either crushed croutons or crushed Ritz crackers, because I never have bread crumbs on hand. I also use minced garlic rather than garlic salt, and it doesn't seem to need additional salt to compensate.
One tip- I would grease the baking sheet or spray with cooking spray prior to placing the meatballs- they come off the sheet a lot cleaner that way.

text:
I made this last night.  I followed the recipe almost exactly except I used half lean ground beef and 1/2 ground pork.  It came out really well. I did use all the red pepper flakes and the hot sauce and it was a bit spicy for me.  I really liked it but next time I might cut the spice in half.  My boyfriend likes spicy food and it was just fine for him but he agreed if we make it for anyone else we need to cut the spice is half atleast.  I also cut the salt in half since we were also using garlic salt and the worcestershire sauce can be salts as well.  I may add in the salt next time to see if it makes a difference.  I didn't notice the recipe lacking salt and it wasn't too salty.  I baked these in the oven for 20min and then simmered them in a pot of tomato sauce for about 40 minutes.  I served it over spaghetti squash, as my bf is diabetic and served broccoli and cheese with it.  I would definitely make this again.  Very good meatball recipe.

This recipe produced a very flavorful (somewhat spicy) meatball.  I did have to make a few changes, but nothing drastic.  I used 1/2 lb. ground beef and a 1/2 lb. ground venison, 1% milk, and 1/2 tsp. crushed red pepper.  I might decrease the onion next time or use the dried minced onion, as DH thought these were too "oniony," though I had no problem with it.  Next time I'll be sure to double the recipe and freeze some for a quick meal.  Thanks!

country:

text:
I actually haven't tried the original recipe; as I printed it out I chef-inspirationally modified the ingredients for a super tender and delicious meatball, and the result was 5-star. I used fattier 80/20 beef. Instead of the onion diced, I grated it on the small side of the grater for an extra fine texture. Instead of the garlic salt I used a large clove of fresh garlic, crushed (mince it and use kosher salt as an abrasive and the back of your knife to mash it into a paste). Instead of Italian seasoning I used 1 tsp. dry basil, 1 tsp. fresh thyme minced, 1 tsp. fresh rosemary minced, and 2 tsp. dry oregano. I kept the red pepper flakes, dash hot sauce (Frank's!), and Worc. sauce. Instead of the skim milk I used an egg. Kept the parm. cheese, and used plain bread crumbs instead of seasoned (because of the seasonings already in the meat). When I baked it I put the meatballs in a 9x13 baking dish and filled it with water about a third up the meatballs. This steams them at the same time and keeps everything super moist and tender. Doing it this way came out very good! Thanks for the great base recipe, I'll be making them like this again!

I loved these !! My husband did my too! I followed the recipe except I used 2% milk. I rolled them into to 10 LARGE meatballs. It made for a gorgeous presentation. I also made my owned seasoned breadcrumbs since I only had plain in the pantry. I will do this every single time !!! INCREDIBLE dinner paired with from scratch marinara sauce and  Linguini pasta !!!! 

INGREDIENTS

1  cup plain breadcrumbs
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/2 teaspoon dried parsley flakes
1/2 teaspoon ground black pepper
1/2 teaspoon garlic powder
1/4 teaspoon onion powder
1/4 teaspoon dried oregano
1/4 teaspoon dried basil

text:
This is pretty much the best meatball recipe ever!  I made it almost exactly as written though I subbed eggs for the milk, made it GF by using Quinoa Flakes instead of breadcrumbs and grated the onion on a box grater so the onion would be fully cooked.  It really makes a difference to mix all the wet ingredients and seasonings with the breadcrumbs/quinoa flakes and let sit for 10-20 minutes first before mixing with the meat (I would recommend doing this especially if you're using the quinoa flakes so they have a chance to soften up)  The only thing I would do different next time (and I'm already looking forward to next time with how awesome they turned out) would be to use garlic powder and/or fresh garlic instead of garlic salt as I found them a touch too salty, though not overly so.  All in all, a really excellent recipe!

text:
We've been using the recipe for a couple of years now.  It is our GOTO recipe for meatballs.  We use dried minced onions instead of fresh and it still turns out great.  That's the only thing we've done different, until last night.

Last night I decided to try frying them!  OMG!   Just a little dab of olive oil in a hot pan.  At first, you'll have to manually flip the meatballs as they fry, but once they've gotten a sear around most of the outer area, you can just jostle the pan around to keep them spinning.   I didn't fry them to the point that they were finished.  Instead, I put them in the oven once they got a good sear.  I only had to cook them in the oven for 7 or 8 minutes before they were finished.  And they didn't bathe in grease while cooking in the oven because frying them got most of the grease out.   Absolutely delicious!

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars, because my family loved it. However, even omitting the hot sauce and cutting down on the red pepper, it was too spicy for me. So word of caution to those like me: JUST CUT OUT THE RED PEPPER AND HOT SAUCE. It is flavorful enough without them. ;)

I tripled the recipe, because it said the recipe made 12 meatballs. I was like, "Uh, that seems like a small number. I need more than that." Well, I ended up with over 100 3/4-1" meatballs. TIP: Mix this in your Kitchen-Aid mixer! Less messy. Then use a small cookie scoop to scoop them out in uniform balls.

After 25 minutes in the oven (we like them well done), I simmered the meatballs in sauce and served over sub rolls. The rest are going in the freezer. :)

text:
These are awesome cooked in the crock pot!  After trying it the way the recipe stated, I did make these changes:  I did half grass fed ground beef and half Italian Sausage.  I substituted the milk for an egg.  I also used panko Italian seasoned breadcrumbs.  Also, make sure you use real parm cheese - no fake stuff!  I doubled the recipe and made smaller sized balls.  I cooked them on low in the crock pot in 2 jars of sauce, a can of diced tomatoes, and I added a package of mushrooms and a zucchini that were cooked in butter/olive oil and garlic before adding to the sauce mixture.  You will be left with a nice thick meaty sauce and delicious meatballs :)

When a recipe comes out great the first time it makes me so happy!  I got the highest praise from hubby who said they are better than his.  I guess I did make a few changes now that I think on it.  I used the pork, veal, beef mixture.  I used Italian flavored Panko, Japanese style breadcrumbs, and soaked it in the 1%milk before adding it last to the mixture.  I also used Pecorino Romano cheese instead of Parmesan because I like it the best.  I also followed another raters suggestion and flipped them 1/2 way through baking.  I will be eternally grateful for that tip since frying is bad for you but they never brown right when baked and now they do!

Loved! I always do three pounds at once so I can freeze a serving. I also always do 1 pound ground turkey with 2 pounds ground beef. So, that is what i did here.  This recipe was great with the addition of the turkey. The seasoning  is great! I only cut back on the salt and red pepper a bit. I used 2 eggs and about a 1/2 - 3/4 cup hot water instead of milk. Ina garden uses hot water and it is truly the best tip for keeping meatballs soft and not hard bricks of meat! Just add enough hot water to really loosen up the mixture so it is soft and mushy. Can't go wrong. Thanks for a great recipe!

I'm going to be honest. I had to change the recipe up A LOT because I have more than 1 family member with a sensitive tummy. I completely omitted the pepper flakes, hot sauce (which I just put on my own meatballs after cooking) and cheese, and I subbed soy milk for the skim milk. Also, I was out of Italian Seasoning, so I subbed Poultry Seasoning (which is basically Italian Seasoning with black pepper and nutmeg). I used 1 tablespoon of the Poultry Seasoning because my bread crumbs were not seasoned which was my bad. Next time I will do as another reviewer suggested and just add more oregano. Still, this recipe yielded the moistest meatballs I have ever eaten. I ate the leftovers last night, and they were still pretty moist ofter being nuked in the microwave. Thank you for sharing, LTH!

text:
These meatballs are so easy to make! They taste great and my favorite part about them is that they freeze even better. I bake up a big batch of them at once and freeze for quick easy meals during the month. To reheat for a juicy meatball, I throw frozen meatballs into a saucepan with a little bit of water, cover with a lid and let them steam, stirring occasionally and/or adding more water so they don't stick to the bottom. They always come out tasting fresh and juicy!

text:
These were SOOO GOOD!!! My boyfriend told me they were even better than our favorite Italian restaurant's meatballs. I did make a few minor changes, but still stayed true to the recipe's overall taste. I used one egg instead of the skim milk, panko bread crumbs instead of Italian (it's what I had on hand)...since I substituted for panko, I doubled the Italian seasoning. I also added fresh oregano instead of dried (again, it's what I had on hand). When using fresh herbs, I learned that the ratio to fresh to dry is 3:1. So I used about one TABLEspoon of the freshly chopped oregano. (3 tsp yield 1 TBS). I didn't have garlic salt so I doubled the salt, and added 1/2 teaspoon of garlic powder. It turned out amazingly delicious!!!! My search for the perfect meatballs is over. :)

Made these last night.  They were fantastic.  I may have heaped my chili flakes a little too much for my husband's liking but I thought they were great.  I noticed he ate any remaining meatballs so that crack about them being a little too spicey may not mean much when all is said and done.

text:
Hats off to this recipe! You rock my world ... it's the best meatball recipe I ever tasted. I changed a few in the recipe though. Like the garlic salt ... since I don't have garlic salt when I made this I just mixed 3 parts of salt to 1 part of garlic powder. Then I used table salt instead of the sea salt. I used only 1/4 teaspoon of crushed red pepper flakes. And then I also used beaten egg to replace the skim milk. The taste of my finish meatballs was so perfect that everyone in the family is looking forward for another meatball nirvana day. Thanks lovestohost for hosting this recipe =)

text:
This came out really good. Very flavorful and moist. I've always cooked meatballs on a flying pan, but I think baking in the oven works better. I made small changes, but for the most part, I stuck with the original recipe. I added an egg, reduced milk to about 1/4 cup. Also added chopped parsley, because I love parsley in meatballs. I LOVE spicy food, but because of my love for spicy food, I have the tendency to overdo the spice. So, just to test it out, I only added 1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper, and did not add any hot sauce. 

Results: I think 3/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper would be OK. Next time, I'm gonna up the spice. Also, as some of the other reviewers have noted, I thought it was a little on the salty side. I think I'm going to add only a little bit of sea salt and 1/2 tsp garlic salt next time around. All in all, great recipe! Thank you!!

Followed the recipe exactly except, I sauteed the onion until tender before adding.  These meatballs had the family saying, 'wow, what did you do different to the meatballs? They're awesome!'.  My family eats meatballs, many meatballs, and NEVER make comments on the taste.  And I have to agree, they were different in the way that you thought...someone who knows how to make meatballs, made these!  Don't be afraid of leaving out the egg, it turns out perfectly.  The texture is what you expect but better.  Good flavor and tasty.  Every bite is just as good as the one before.  No shortage of salt or seasoning with a good tender, cut with a fork texture.  Try these.  You won't be sorry.

text:
The name of this recipe is SPOT.ON.  These are absolutely DELICIOUS!!  

I did make a few changes and doubled the recipe because I'd bought 2 lbs. of ground beef/pork/veal.  

Since I only had one slice of bread on hand, I tore it up and figured it to be about 1/4 c. when crumbled.  I then supplemented with 3/4 c. oats and added both to the food processor so I wouldn't have big oat flakes in the meatballs.

After emptying the bread crumbs/oats, I added 2 cloves of garlic and the roughly chopped onion to the food processor to get a nice mince.  I sweat that in 2 Tbs. olive oil over medium heat for about 5-7 minutes.  Removed from heat and let cool a few minutes, then mixed in the bread/oats.

From there, I followed the recipe directions for mixing and baking, turning the meatballs half-way through baking.  

I hadn't eaten lunch yet when they came out of the oven and was tempted to stuff myself silly with meatballs!  YUM!  Finally a meatball recipe that reminds me of my Italian grandmother's.  Thanks LTH!

I did find that using a whole diced onion had a tendency to make my meatballs TOO moist, causing them to fall apart when I put them in my sauce, so I usually just use onion powder instead. I myself have never been much of a meatball fan, but after making these I am an official convert.

WOW. these are incredible! used others advice and used an egg instead of the milk-- no problems there. also, used 80/20 and they were perfectly moist after cooking. made my own bread crumbs from a toasted baguette and seasoned them with chicken grill seasoning. also, didnt have any italian seasoning so i did about 3/4 t dried basil and about 1/4 t marjoram in addition to the oregano. added about a tsp of sriracha and these came out with a kick! so good... we put these on the rest of the baguettes with some spaghetti sauce and havarti, instant meatball sub. will definitely make these again and again.

oh, also, i had a 1" cookie scoop so i just used that to make these meatballs and only had to cook them for about 8-9 minutes. perfectly moist and tender so make sure you watch them!

I made 3 pounds of these back in august and froze them raw. I also used them to make burgers out of [also froze them raw. first froze in layers on a tray with wax paper and then transferred into a ziplock]--they are delicious and so handy for quick meals. When I want to make meatball parm, I cook them in some sauce in a saucepan. Other times, I just put the frozen meat balls whole into a pot of pasta sauce and break up the meatballs as it defrosts for an amazingly yummy meat sauce. Ive also used this meat sauce in lasagna and ziti. My husband LOVES the flavor of these and they come out really moist. My only problem with these is that some of them would crack a little as I cooked them, but the recipe *does* call for baking them, so I can't take stars off for that. I made another batch of these today [but forgot the hot sauce ::sad face::] and will try baking them before cooking them in the sauce and see how it goes.

I had 1.5 pounds of ground beef to use so I decided to make these meatballs. I am SO glad I tried this recipe!  It is the best ever. I baked them in the oven for about 20 minutes and then put the meatballs in a large straight-sided pan and added 26 oz of Hunts spaghetti sauce and a drizzle of olive oil. Let simmer on low for about 15 minutes covered. Served in a bowl with some of the sauce and a couple of tbsp of Tassos Mediterranean olive salad which I got at Costco. Fabulous meal! 
Put single servings of the leftovers in ziplock baggies, put all of those in a big ziplock and they are in the freezer ready on a moment's notice. This will definitely be my go-to meatball recipe from now on. Thanks so much for posting this!

This recipe is awesome.  It is of mild spiciness.  Make it exactly as stated the first time and tweak in future builds.

I personally add a little wheat germ (for health) and use more crushed red pepper than suggested.  Worcestershire sauce is not needed in my opinion.  

I recommend using half beef and half ground turkey if you want a healthier mix.  100% beef is awesome but the 50/50 mix of beef turkey is probably 80-90% as good.  It's a good option if you are looking to make it a little healthier.

I did tinker with garlic once.  Give it a shot but it really does not improve the taste.

text:
I made these last night since my kids asked for meatballs for dinner.  I didn't have time to read the reviews so I followed the recipe exactly and here is what I found out.  You don't need the 1/2 teaspoon sea salt it calls for, the garlic salt, Worcestershire sauce and Parmesan cheese provide plenty of salt on their own (and I believe the bread crumbs have some as well) and instead of dicing the onion, I will be grating it next time.  The cooking time in my oven was around 20 minutes, any longer would have made the meatballs overcooked.  Also, if you are making these for small kids, you might want to omit hot pepper sauce or crushed red peppers or both.  I used both and my kids were fine.

All 3 of my kids, even my picky 6 year old LOVED them.  Thank you for posting it.

text:
UPDATE: MADE THESE AGAIN TONIGHT (BOY, IT'S BEEN A LOOONG TIME!) AND THEY WERE SIMPLY A-W-E-S-O-M-E!!! THESE ARE EVEN GREAT ON THEIR OWN ALTHOUGH I'D NEVER DO THAT (MB'S WITHOUT SAUCE JUST SEEMS UNORTHODOX TO ME...). I THINK THE KEY IS USING A GOOD HOT SAUCE (I.E. FRANK'S) AND SEVERAL GOOD DASHES OF IT. THESE WERE OUT OF THE OVEN IN 20 MINUTES AND OUR MB SUBS WERE ASSEMBLED IN UNDER 5 (YIPPIE!!!). THANKS AGAIN, LTH! :) Hooray for Italian night - spaghetti, meatballs and homemade garlic bread (Mmmmm...)!!! I've been searching high and low for a good meatball recipe, and these just might be it. Prep was SO easy, I'd do a repeat on that basis alone! And, using my Pampered Chef 3 T scoop made forming even-sized meatballs purely effortless. TIP: If you lightly spray each meatball with Pam cooking spray, they will crisp up nicely in the oven (if you like your MB's browned with a slightly crispy exterior). I have also found that placing your meatballs on a rack INSIDE a roasting pan will help keep the grease at bay. All in all, these were good, but I'm not convinced these are the "end all be all" MB's (at least not for me). If you're looking for the perfect meatball for sub sandwiches, these are definitely it tho - these babies are firm (not mushy) and hold their shape really well. Thanks for sharing, LTH. These seem to be the BOMB on here! :-)

Delicious.  I was craving spaghetti but was too lazy to make sauce so I decided to put some homemade meatballs into jarred sauce I've had sitting for a while.  These meatballs definitely took the jarred sauce up a few levels and became an amazing comfort food dinner.  I had to make a few subs based on what I had on hand.  1.  ~2 tbsp minced onions instead of real onions.  2.  Soy milk instead of normal milk (can't drink it).  3. No hot sauce.  4. text:
I made it tonight and my mouth is still burning from the red pepper. Way too much! 
Take away the red pepper, add sauted green peppers and finely chopped onions, add one egg, 1/2 cup of typical bread crumbs and 1/2 cup of homemade breadcrumbs (I got a French bread from the store and cut it in half and tore off pieces and let them sit for a few hours) 
Form meatballs, brown them in skillet. Add sauce and simmer for about 45 minutes. 
Your mouth will thank you

I used half lean beef and half ground pork, and replaced the skim milk with half a cup of ricotta cheese.  Used recommended amount of chili flakes and 5 dashes Chipotle  Tabasco. Noticeable heat but not overwhelming for anyone who like buffalo sauce equivalent or more.
Had to cook for 45 min on 400 and finished on high broil for approx 5 min. (note: the meatballs were 2" wide) 
Might want to consider searing in a pan before or after to achieve a more desired outer texture and look.  The broil added a little bit of crunch to the top but could definitely go for more coverage. Also, maybe try smaller diameter next time.

text:
Pretty good, I made it last night. But, I never use garlic salt, I always use garlic powder or fresh minced garlic. I also use fresh parsley in my meatballs, & I divide the meat by using ground round, & then an equal amount of fresh ground pork, so it doesnt end up dry. I dont use milk, but I do use a can of stewed Italian tomatos , including the juice. I chop the tomatos. I add a whole beaten egg, onion powder, coarse black pepper, salt, Italian seasoning , with my fresh minced garlic, & chopped finely parsley. The fresh Parmesan is essential. And I make my own seasoned bread crumbs. Believe me its worth the extra effort. 
But, I wanted to try this, & no offense it could not compare to mine

text:
I love this recipe! I've made numerous adjustments though: I use turkey instead of beef (make sure to get 93% lean, 7% fat), but that's just to be "healthy". Dice the onions very finely. I tend to have a heavy hand with the hot sauce and only put in 1/2 tsp of red pepper flakes. I've started adding about 1/4 tsp parsley, and make the garlic salt a very rounded 1/2 tsp. I do not add the sea salt at all. I use just a tad less than 2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce. Since that adds some more moisture to the mix I go a little less on the milk, just shy of the 1/3 cup.

I LOOOVEE this recipe!  It is fast and easy to make, and the name is very fitting -- true meatball nirvana.  I've made it multiple times now without changing a single ingredient.  Well, other than this last time, swapping out ground beef for ground turkey. country:

text:
This was my first time making homemade meatballs and they turned out great!

I'm not sure how to add notes that I can read next time I make this so I'm going to include them here.    I used 1lb of ground been and 1/2lb of Italian sausage.    For the rest of the ingredients I changed the serving size from 4 to 6.    I used 1tsp of onion powder instead of the small onion, garlic powder instead of garlic salt, an egg with a splash of milk, only half of the red pepper flakes and omitted the hot sauce.

I put the meat together in a ziplock bag and mixed it through the bag then added the egg/milk/worcestershire sauce to the bag to mix with the meat.  In a separate bowl I added all the dry ingredients to the seasoned bread crumbs.     Next I put the meat mixture in the dry ingredient bowl and mixed together.  I divided it into 4 large balls then divided each of those balls into 5 smaller balls which ended up being a little bigger than a golf ball.  I baked on a rack at 400 for 20 minutes and then put them in the crockpot on low with marinara.

text:
I have made these twice, both pretty much following the recipe, but I put a note to review them after trying the changes from "Italian Tapas". 

Both are very good, but I think the changes from Italian Tapas make them even better: swap the 1/3 cup of skim milk for 1/2 cup of ricotta, and use 1/2 pound each of ground pork and ground beef. I could not get lean ground beef,  and used 80/20 and it was fine, especially since the ground pork I get is very lean.

The other things I didn't do: I don't keep garlic salt as I watch my sodium content, so I used granulated garlic, next time I might cut the 1/2 tsp of sea salt-which I also don't keep, to the same amount or less, of kosher salt. I don't get seasoned bread crumbs as there are ingredients in them that I either can't have or don't want to eat. I used 1/2 cup of plain panko and rolled a rolling pin over them first. 

I made a tester to see if I wanted to put fennel seeds in them, and much as I love fennel seed, I didn't add them. I also did not bake them in the oven on a rack, as I usually do. I used my 2-qt air fryer. I preheated it to 390, put half the meatballs in for 5 min. gave them a shake and another 5 min-done. I did them in two batches, but I have a lot less mess to clean up. The air fryer basket is much easier to clean than a gridded cooling/baking rack., AND the air fryer does not heat up the kitchen, which is nice, as we are about 80 today.

Try Meatball Nirvana either way, or both ways and make up your own mind,

Best recipe! I do double it (1 lb. ground beef & 1 lb. ground pork). I also omit the milk, use fresh bread crumbs, fresh garlic (not garlic salt), add 2 eggs and omit the oregano (doubling the Italian seasoning). I usually chill these, portion them out, then freeze them with my vacuum sealer. All you have to do for a quick meal is dump the frozen meatballs in some sauce and simmer until they are thawed. My son LOVES them and I always keep them handy in the freezer for the busy winter months so I have a quick meal in a snap when I get home from work!

text:
I made this recipe as outlined with 1 exception- I didnt add the oregano simply because I somehow ran out and didnt have any and my Italian seasoning has oregano in it already. I LOVE spice- especially spices used in Italian cooking- but it should be balanced. I practically choked on the amount of Italian seasoning in this- so much that, while everything looked well mixed, it was like biting into meat pockets of dry seasoning. Im glad I didnt have the extra oregano or wed have a wasted a pound of meat! Bleh! It was edible drenched in a zesty marinara, but thats the best compliment I can give it. Honestly, cut the Italian seasoning to 1/3 of the recipe, leave out the extra oregano, increase the red pepper flakes an garlic, and youll be much better off than following this to a T.

text:
This is my go-to meatball recipe. Super yummy. Super easy. You can freeze them after you've cooked them so double the recipe and have them again in a month!

This is the sort of recipe that can be easily modified to taste, too. When doubling, I use half ground beef and half Italian sausage. When I do that, I leave off the red pepper flakes to keep the heat back. 

I grew up with my mom's excellent meatballs, but I never wanted to make them because she browned them in a skillet before putting them in the oven and it was so much work! Now, I make meatballs all the time. And, I sold my mom on this method. :)

None
text:
This wasn't *quite* meatball nirvana for us, but it was pretty close! I discovered my spice cabinet was in sad shape when I went to make these, but they still turned out pretty good! I never use real onions in anything, but especially not a meatloaf or meatball or anything like that because they just screw up the appearance and texture. So I used onion powder instead. I didn't have but maybe half of the suggested italian seasoning and I didn't have garlic salt, so just used regular garlic powder, and next time I'd skip the pepper flakes in favor of just regular cayenne. I had some serious doubts that they would stick together without eggs, but they did, sorta. I'm thinking some egg and oatmeal instead of bread crumbs next time would be a good addition. I tossed mine in the instant pot with a quick marinara from the skinnytaste website and pressured them for 10 or 15 minutes, and made them into meatball subs. If you do the same, make small meatballs (learn from my mistakes, people!) and don't be afraid to go heavy with the sauce. A quick trip under the broiler and they were pretty darn awesome!

text:
SUBS: I used 2 teaspoons of onion flakes instead of onion, because I didn't have onion at the time. I didn't have bread crumbs so I crushed standard soup oyster crackers. I used 3 teaspoons of Huy Fong chili garlic sauce as my hot sauce. I used chuck ground beef. (80% muscle/20% fat)

REVIEW: The meatballs were amazing. I tried one (or four, don't judge) about 3 minutes out of the oven and they were amazing. I expected them to not have much structural rigidity, but I was pleasantly surprised at how sturdy they were on their own. The texture is great and tasting the garlic and red chili flakes together really completed the experience. 

I made mine to be spicy, which is why I added the 3 teaspoons of  garlic chili sauce. I really loved how the sauce interacted with the flavors (no vinegar-y taste, added heat and tang), but at times it was overpowering. I if you were to use this sauce I would recommend only 1 teaspoon. Even if you like it spicy, it pays off to dial it back for the sake of retaining the garlic/herb flavor.

5

Very good!  I baked 2 gf everything bagels until they were dry -- about 300 degrees for roughly 30 min.  Then put them in the food processor until crumbs.  I used nutritional yeast for the Parmesan but used only about 1/3 c. instead of a half (for a doubled recipe).  Also, the mixture seemed quite dry so I ended up adding 1/4 c. milk.  I think 2 T. would have been enough.  also used ground cayenne, about 1/2 tsp. and siracha for the hot sauce, about 1/2 tsp.  both were a good amount.  Wouldn't want them more spicy.  Scooped with the 1 1/2" diameter cookie scoop and then made them into balls.  I ended up with 51.  Done at 20 minutes.

Made recipe as stated: Convection oven at 400 took 15 minutes. Moist, good texture and balance of seasoning. However, next time I will omit the additional oregano since the Italian season mix has it. I will also use minced fresh garlic instead of garlic salt (personal preference). I will also go back to my normal way of mixing the meatballs, by making a well of seasonings, breadcrumbs, and milk in the center of meat,  letting the breadcrumbs absorb for 5 minutes, then gently mixing the meat in...this seems to give a slightly better texture to the balls.  Over mixing causes dense meatballs.

The recipe as written is great.

To mix it up with a little variation try this:
(leaves them a little more seasoned)

skip the salt and milk
+ 1 healthy sized shredded carrot
+ 1/4 c finely diced green pepper
+ 3/4 c pizza sauce

+ 1/4 c or so extra breadcrumbs but leave very moist

glass baking dish works better than foil (even oiled) since they stick a tiny bit  to foil

text:
Easy recipe with excellent results!   These are some of the most tender, moist and flavorful meatballs I have ever had!  The only change I made was using cracker crumbs instead of bread crumbs, as I forgot to buy breadcrumbs at the store.  the results were delicious!  I cannot believe how moist the meatballs were,  even without the egg thar many other recipes call for.

Baked the meatballs as directed and then added the cooked meatballs to a good quality jarred marinara sauce.  Served them with  hair and a bit of fresh basil.  Delicious!

I would suggest doubling  (or tripling) the recipie so you can make ahead and freeze.  I did not do so this time, but will definitely do next time!

This recipe was absolutely delicious!! This is one I will be using again. I grew up in an Italian family and we have a "secret sauce" recipe that I usually just add meat to, but I wanted to start trying some good meatball recipes. This was a hit with my picky husband!!

I only rated it 4 stars because I felt there was a bit too much onion, and I used veal instead of ground beef. I also was out of worshteshire, and substituted a smaller amount of soy sauce so that I wouldn't get an Asian flavor. The consistency was tender and SO moist, and the bake time & temp was perfect. Unless you absolutely love onion, I would suggest only using half a small one. It added a whole new flavor to my traditional spaghetti & meat sauce recipe. Will be making for a long time!

This will be my go to recipe for meatballs from now on.

text:
This is a very good recipe. Over time, I've made some changes but the base recipe is great. The two changes I've always made are substituting onion powder for the onion (we don't like onions) and using gluten free breadcrumbs because my husband has Celiac Disease. Other things I've done as I continue to make this include: using garlic powder and a bit more salt instead of garlic salt, using unseasoned breadcrumbs or using 1/3 amount seasoned and 2/3 unseasoned (so the flavoring doesn't overwhelm my sauce), using freshly made hot sauce from our own home-grown peppers (and a bit more to make them spicier) and using freshly granted genuine parmesan. Also, using whatever dairy milk you have (skim or more fat) will not affect the recipe. I prefer them with these changes BUT I think you will enjoy the recipe as rated. These are the only kind I make and my family far prefers them to the pre-made frozen kind, gluten free or with gluten.

text:
Holy meatballs! So, these are the most amazing meatballs I have ever eaten in my life. HOWEVER, I made one really important change. Instead of just ground beef, I made it with half ground beef and half bulk ground pork sausage. Because the sausage has a kick of its own, I left out the crushed red peppers. Mainly because I have a toddler and a four year old I needed to eat these. ;) Otherwise the crushed red peppers probably could have stayed if you like spicy. I also used gluten-free bread crumbs. These did stick terribly to the foil covered baking sheet I used and that did annoy me. I doubled the recipe so I had to do it in two batches. I realized I forgot to coat the foil in oil to prevent sticking the first time so I did it well the second time but they still stuck. :( I think next time I will turn them halfway through and along with oiling the foil first that ought to fix the problem. Regardless, we were all fighting over these meatballs and they went so fast! I was so pleased and amazed that my usually picky toddler was actually happily destroying them! And he ate at least two at a time every time I heated some up for us for the few days they were around. :D That's a lot of meatball for a little guy who isn't even two yet. In fact, on the last reheated serving of them, my toddler ate all that I gave him and tried to take my husband's and it is literally the first time I have ever seen him refuse to share his dinner with his kid when solicited for some of his food. Haha!

I couldn't find seasoned breadcrumbs, so I used a packet of Italian seasoned coating mix for chicken. Because of this switch-up, I found the meatballs a tad salty, but otherwise yummy. I MAY have left them in the oven a little longer than necessary because the bottoms were a little over-browned, so I WILL make these again, but if I use the coating mix again, I will reduce or eliminate the sea salt, plus I will take them out of the oven after 20 minutes baking, instead of the 25 or 30 minutes I baked them for this time! Practice makes perfect!

I made these as written with the exception of using less red pepper flakes, I used 1/4 tsp as there are RPF's in my Italian spice mix.  To me the texture is a bit odd, much like a frozen meatball.  I don't see the point of mixing most of the ingredients and then adding in the milk, cheese and breadcrumbs and mixing again. Ground beef should be mixed only to combine the ingredients, over mixing creates a dense, tough meatball.  I think that they would benefit from fresh garlic and some parsley.

text:
Only meatball recipe I use. I use panko Italian seasoned breadcrumbs but still add the rest of the seasonings. My sweetheart (who is full Italian) said they are as good as his mom's. My kids love these. I make them whenever we have spaghetti. They are a staple in our home. I've tried them fried and baked. I usually fry them in batches for about 3 minutes on each side, put them in a bowl to drain, drain off the extra oil from the pan but leave some of the bits in the pan, add the no sugar added tomato basil sauce from a jar, scrape the bits into the sauce, bring the sauce up to a simmer, and return them to the pan to simmer in the sauce, covered, for about 10 minutes. Perfection. Thank you for this outstanding recipe.

REMINDER: WARM MEAT TO ROOM TEMPERATURE. This is just to save the pain in your hands when you mix the  meat. I always forget when I make meatloaf and I forgot when I made this dish. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a large batch, used 3.7 lb pkg of 90% lean Ground beef.  To adjust to this amount I minced 1 large onion and 4 lg garlic cloves. 1/4 cup fresh chopped parsley and oregano combined. 1 small deveined and de-seeded fresh cayenne chili pepper minced. 1 Tbsp dried oregano, 1 Tbsp dried basil, 2 tsp salt, 1 tsp black pepper, 1 tsp dried red pepper flakes, 1 Cup Italian Style bread crumbs. Stirred all these ingredients in bowl to combine thoroughly. In separate bowl I beat 1 egg, 2 Tbsp Worschestershire Sauce, 3 splashes of Tabasco sauce and 1/4 cup of milk. Stirred liquid ingredients into dry. Mixed ground beef by hand into final mixture. Baked 2" diameter meatballs at 400 degrees for 20 minutes, baked 1" mini meatballs at 400 degrees for 10 minutes. Made 40 large and 30 mini meatballs. Taste Great!!

Try adding Soy Sauce instead of Worcestershire sauce... Its amazing. Use cold hamburger meat. Oh and hand mixing everything in also is great. (Separate the liquids and the solids and the hamburger and then once every section is mixed up dump the onions into the liquid, mix and then pour into the mushed up hamburger and once mixed completely pour in the dry section and squeeze with hands until everything is evenly mixed.) I made a double batch so that can also be something. And i also make the meatballs smaller about an inch in diameter. Hope you enjoy.

text:
I've made these twice. I followed the recipe the first time and it needed some more flavor, needed to hold together better, and I almost felt like they were a little dry. Made them gain with 90/10 lean ground beef. I used kosher salt and simply used a dash more, switched the garlic salt to garlic powder (otherwise it would be too salty), also used a little more union and had it finely diced. I ended up adding in more of the Italian seasoning and red pepper flakes which I think went well. Cooked for 24 minutes. After round two, it still didn't really hold like I wanted, flavors were better, but this time felt too moist. I would cut back on the milk and the onion, add in an egg white, and up the bread crumbs and Parmesan just to try and give it some more hold considering I've seen eggs used in every other meatball recipe.

These are my favorite meatballs and I've been making this recipe for a couple of years now.  I'm only giving 4 stars because I tweak them a little from the original and then they are AMAZING! Seriously, these are some of the best meatballs!

text:
First, let me assure you - these meatballs are fantastic!! Now, I know some people like to blast other people for rating recipes that they have modified. Oh well. Blast away! Here's what I changed:  I doubled the recipe, but instead of 2 lbs of ground beef, I used 1 lb ground beef and 1 lb ground pork. I feel this significantly added to the recipe. Also, I used 2 cloves of minced garlic versus garlic salt. The fresh garlic is much better in my opinion. I skip the hot sauce and red pepper flakes and instead used cayenne pepper, smoked paprika, and a little chipotle chili powder. I also added a tablespoon of brown sugar. Also, instead of grated parmesan, I used a blend of parmesan, romano and asiago. Oh, and I beat 1 egg into the milk prior to adding it. The results? FANTASTIC. Like, can't-keep-your-hands-off-them good. It made about 55 good sized meatballs. I cooked them and then froze them in convenient sized batches. Perfect for pulling out after work for a quick meal. I thought this recipe was an excellent base and if a person makes a few personalized tweaks, they can have the perfect meat ball for their family.

Before I try any new recipe, I always read the ingredients very carefully. If there are ratings and reviews, all the better to read before I begin making the recipe. This is one reason allrecipes.com is my top site for recipes and food ideas, because they also provide reviews and comments. I did not change this recipe at all, which is how I try and start all new recipes, as it looked very basic and good to me. And it was very good. Husband loved them. I did not turn them, nor make any ingredient substitutions. They did have a slight peppery, hot bite but not much at all and I thought that made for a more complex flavor and liked that. I made a double batch so I am pleased that I liked them very much. Only changes next time would be to dice the onions more finely and try Panko crumbs, which is my personal favorite for bread crumbs. This one goes in My Cookbook!

text:
Made a couple small changes..half ground beef, half mild or hot Italian sausage and instead of skim milk, I used evaporated milk.  These things are addictive.  We love them with a favorite from scratch sauce (yeah, the one that takes all day) but equally as good with another favorite right out of the jar!  These meatballs make the best meatball subs smothered in provolone and any sauce you choose. I have doubled the recipe and after shaping into meatballs, put them on a cookie sheet and froze them, then put them into freezer safe bags so I could take out as many or as few as needed for me and DH or for when the gangs all here.  Positively perfect meatballs!!

I modified the recipe a bit to suit my tastes and they turned out spectacular!  I left out the Italian seasoning and oregano as my bread crumbs were "Italian seasoned." text:
Thank you LTH! This is a meatball recipe to end all meatball recipes, a keeper. I did not have breadcrumbs so I threw a handful of croutons in the food processor and used that instead. I did turn them over at the ten minute mark as they were Browning nicely and wanted to keep it even. Didn't have oregano or hot sauce on hand so threw in another pinch of Italian seasoning. Heck I only had about a tablespoon of parmesan and these still turned out amazing.Kept their shape (a problem with other recipes I have tried-a meatball does not an egg need) served on toasted French bread for the finest meatball sub in the land. Thanks again, end product was happy husband and kids were in a state of nirvana...meatball nirvana.

I made this recipe last night. It was one of the lightest and delicious meatballs I've ever had! Perhaps because I made them, but nonetheless here is how I prepared them - I doubled the recipe, using 1 lb of organic ground beef and 1 lb organic ground chuck. I followed the recipe for the most part but used siracha hot sauce (we like it hot hot hot) I doubled the amount of herbs and pepper flakes used. Used one big fat onion and put a whole head of garlic in the beef. They were fantastic! It made about 35 meatballs, great for freezing and using for another occasion.

text:
I love these meatballs! I've tried a few different recipes and was never particularly excited about any of them . . . until I found this one. Really great flavor. It's probably the hot sauce and chili flakes that make it stand out, and those are things I generally don't cook with and/or use with caution as I'm not a fan of super spicy foods, but these are not spicy at all. I've used this recipe a couple of times and also had my teenage daughter make it once. I've don't have an "italian seasoning" blend so I just put in the italian seasonings what I have, such as oregano, basil, and garlic powder. I have made it with regular bread crumbs (usually plain) and panko breadcrumbs and both work well. I never buy skim milk, so use whatever I have, either whole or 2%. I generally never measure anything and they always seem turn out great. I think they're hard to mess up. ;) I'm making some tonight and think I'll double the recipe and freeze some.

text:
I used Italian breadcrumbs and added some minced garlic (the jarred kind and drizzled some of the juice in as well). I would recommend dicing the onions into itty-bitty pieces otherwise your meatballs look like they have tumors. I cooked on 400 for 11 minutes and then down to 385 and threw in a loaf of ciabatta. I then cut off a chunk of ciabatta, sliced it in half, sprinkled on Provel (yes, Provel, not provolone)and more minced garlic and heated up tomato sauce from The Hill. Then I sliced two meatballs in half, placed on burn-the-roof-of-your-mouth Provel cheesy bread and smothered in tomato sauce. Mmmmm. Almost as good as Fassi's.

I did tweak this recipie a bit.  I knew 12 meatballs would only last about an hour in my house and I wanted some for the freezer. I added 1 lb. of italian sausage and 1 lb of veal.  I read an article where it said that a good meatball contained all three meats.

I trippled all of the spices and cheese and cooked for 20 minutes.

These are the bomb and I will make them again!

text:
I don't eat beef, but wanted some good meatballs for my beef-eating family. I used panko crumbs because they are just simple ingredients: wheat flour, dextrose, yeast, salt (the regular bread crumbs were made of bread containing high fructose corn syrup and lots of additives). Like LTH suggested, I also used dried minced onion to omit the step of chopping an onion. I was out of milk, so I used 2 eggs and a splash of half 'n' half in a triple recipe. Froze the leftovers. My family says they're WAY better than store-bought frozen meatballs!! Thanks LTH!

text:
Perfectly easy and tasty meatball recipe! I ran out of bread crumbs (I was making this with 5# of meat! Yielding around 150 meatballs) so I subbed some Ritz crackers. Using a cookie scoop to form the meatballs is a quick trick to uniform size. I also like to bake them on a cooling rack over a foil-lined pan; it was about 20 minutes for the size of ball I made. After cooling completely, I popped them in the freezer for a week or two. After spending the morning on low in the crockpot, covered with sauce, they were thawed and ready to eat! They went over very well at the party!

Really enjoyed these!  Our usual meatball recipe is done on the stovetop, so, these are nice in that you don't have to stand about turning them all the time.  :)  We liked them just fine as is, but, do swap a few things from time to time, such as changing up the cheese to Swiss or mozzarella, just for variety.  We grind the red pepper flakes a bit as they can be a bit crunchy, not a texture we prefer.  We also up the "spicy" with some extra hot sauce, a little cayenne, or some finely-chopped jalapeno peppers.  Good go-to recipe.

text:
These meatballs were quite good.  I made them and placed them on a cookie sheet in the freezer til frozen then transferred them into a ziploc bag.  Just took 9 meatballs out and put them in the toaster oven at 350 for 30 minutes before heating up some tomato sauce to make sandwiches.  A few modifications:  
- Because I want to make them for meatball sandwiches, I didn't make them completely round.  I just flattened them a bit, so they'd fit better in the bread
- I had to leave out the peppers and hot sauce to appease the kids. I'm sure they taste great with the peppers, but even without the sauce, I found it to be tasty
- I have also increased the amount of onions, carmelized them and then added them in once cooled.  Otherwise, if using raw, I'll mince instead of dice. When I tried dicing, I thought the onions were a bit overpowering.

text:
Update 3/8/2016: Four years later and this is still my favorite meatball recipe. I have since made it exactly as the recipe states and it is excellent! I made a double batch a couple years ago for a family holiday potluck/party, and I served it in marinara sauce with French bread on the side and it was gone in no time, everyone loved these meatballs. I made them again tonight, and they are ridiculously quick to make and cook, even on a weeknight! 
Original review: So I usually buy the pre-made meatballs from Whole Foods butcher section, that you cook yourself, and today was no different. But when I got to the butcher section, they had no meatballs! Luckily, they had lean grass-fed bef on sale, so I picked up a pound, knowing I'd be able to find a great recipe on Allrecipes! This recipe was my final choice, for several reasons: a) it's egg-free (food sensitivities on my part) b) it's simple, made with stuff I generally have on hand and c)they're baked. That said, I was missing a couple ingredients. I forgot to pick up milk when shopping, I had no Worcestershire sauce on hand, and the only breadcrumbs I usually have around are panko. These were my workarounds - I used water in place of milk, and added some veggie bullion paste that has a similar flavor to Worcestershire sauce to the water. I added the veggie bullion water to the panko, to moisten it, then added it to the meat mixture and mixed well. What I noticed is that the raw mixture smelled very similar to the meatballs I

text:
I found nothing truly spectacular about these. Yes, they are quick and easy for a weekday dinner, and that is important to me as a working mom, but taste-wise, I wasn't impressed. I left out the red pepper flakes and hot sauce, as my 3 year-old was eating these, however I doubt it would've made them any better. I increased the garlic and decreased the Italian seasoning, which contains oregano, which I don't particularly care for. Even with far less Italian seasoning than called for, the oregano flavor definitely overpowered the meatballs. Baking at 400 degrees seemed too high, so I baked them at 375 instead. However, baking them at 350 for the same cooking time would've sufficed. Hubby really liked these, but I probably won't use this recipe again. I'll keep searching for my idea of "meatball nirvana" but thank you for the submission nonetheless.

PHENOMENAL!!!  I did change it a tad though... doubled everything except red pepper flakes but used 1# beef and 1# pork.  LOVE these meat balls!  If you're reading these reviews wondering "what makes these meatballs different from all the other recipes?"  I'll tell you... No EGG.
